# Draft:Council of Scientific Society Presidents

----
CSSP, or the Council of Scientific Society Presidents, is an organization in the United States that brings together presidents, past presidents, and presidents-elect of scientific societies and federations. Its role is to foster science leadership, to coordinate among scientific organizations, and to influence science policy, education, and communication at national and international levels.
History
CSSP was founded in 1973..
Over its history it has evolved from a relatively quiet forum into a more active voice in science policy and leadership development.
One of its long-serving leaders is Martin A. Apple, who served as President & CEO (a part-time role) from about 1993 until 2012.
In 2015, Madeleine Jacobs, formerly CEO of the American Chemical Society (ACS), was named President & CEO of CSSP, following her retirement from ACS.
Membership
The membership comprises presidents, past presidents, and presidents-elect of approximately 60 scientific societies and federations.
At peak membership, these societies together represented over 1.4 million scientists and science educators.
Mission, Goals, and Activities
CSSP carries out a number of functions:
Leadership Development: Helping society heads strengthen their skills, share experiences, and lead their societies effectively.
Policy and Advocacy: Deliberating and adopting public-policy positions on issues such as science education, research funding, communication, ethics, and emerging scientific challenges.
Public Understanding of Science: Promoting better communication between scientists and the public, raising awareness of scientific issues and the importance of science in society.
Networking & Coordination: Serving as a forum for scientific societies’ leadership to share best practices, collaborate, and coordinate responses to national/international scientific issues
According to one past member "The meetings are jam-packed — a Saturday of leadership training, followed by a couple of days of rapid-fire, top-level briefings on national and world affairs in science, a penultimate lesson on how to lobby and an ultimate congressional breakfast (in situ), with lobbying then and afterward. Evenings and coffee breaks are filled by sessions of networking with the movers and shakers in Washington science policy, and with the movers and shakers who are presidents of other scientific societies."
Leadership
Martin A. Apple was CSSP President & CEO from 1993 to 2012 and then President Emeritus and Research and Development Director until 2024.
Madeleine Jacobs took over as President & CEO in 2015, succeeding interim president Gordon L. Nelson.
Membership Societies & Federations
CSSP’s membership includes presidents of ~60 societies and federations across scientific disciplines (e.g., biology, chemistry, physics, ecology, engineering). These are U.S. (and sometimes international) scientific societies whose presidents or leadership are engaged in science education, research, policy, etc. Some members have included such societies as the American Academy of Forensic Sciences, American institute of Biological Sciences, American Institute of Physics, American Mathematical Society, American Society for lnformation Science and Technology, American Chemical Society, Association for Computing Machinery, Association for Women in Science, Computing Research Association, Association for the Sciences of Limnology and Oceanography SPIE, International Society for Optical Engineering, Society for lndustrial and Applied Mathematics, Linguistic Society of America, Institute of Food Technologists, Soil Science Society of America, Crop Science Society of America, Sigma Xi, Association for the Education of Teachers in Science and Institute for Operations Research and Management Sciences., among many others.
Notable Events & Programs
CSSP provides awards/honors; for example, the Carl Sagan Award for Public Understanding of Science is associated with CSSP.
It often serves as a coordinating body when scientific societies need to respond jointly to policy proposals or funding changes. (E.g., communicating to Congress, engaging with federal agencies.)
Significance
CSSP plays a unique role:
By focusing on the society presidents and leadership, it helps align priorities across many fields of science.
It can speak with clout, because the member societies represent very large numbers of individual scientists and educators.
It acts as a bridge between scientific societies (which often focus on discipline‐specific issues) and broader science policy, education, and public engagement issues.
